# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Sure, here is how you can implement it:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    df[:audi_a4_type] = (df.manufacturer .== "audi") .& (df.model .∈ ["a4", "a4 quattro"])
    return df
end
```
This function uses the DataFrames package in Julia to manipulate dataframes. The `.==` operator is used for element-wise comparison of two arrays and `.∈` is a broadcasting version of `in`. It checks if each element of `df.manufacturer` equals "audi" and if each element of `df.model` is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". The result of these comparisons are then combined using the bitwise AND operator `.&`, which returns `true` only where both conditions are met.

You can test this function with your DataFrame like so:

```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
                   model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
df_cars = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
After running this code, `df_cars` will contain a new column `:audi_a4_type` where all rows are `true` if the car is an Audi A4 or A4 Quattro and false otherwise.
